questions.text: Which of the following correctly lists the layers of the sclera from outermost to innermost?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Episclera > Sclera proper > Lamina fusca

 

Explanation:

  • The sclera consists of three ill-defined layers, namely the sclera proper with the episclera on the outside and the lamina fusca interiorly.

Layers of the Sclera:

Layer

Description

Composition

Remarks

Episclera

Thin vascularized. connective tissue.
  • Collagen fibers
  • Fibroblasts
  • Blood vessels
  • Nerves

Located just outside the sclera proper

Sclera proper
  • Relatively avascular.
  • Dense tissue.
  • Dense irregular bundles of collagen (compared to the orderly arrangement in the cornea)
  • Elastic fibers Fibroblasts, Proteoglycans
  • The thickest layer of the sclera
  • Provides structural support and integrity

Lamina fusca
  • Innermost layer.
  • Loose connective
  • tissue layer.

Melanocytes (migrated from choroid)

It contains pigmented cells derived from the choroid

questions.text:
Match the scleral apertures with the structures they transmit


	
		
			 
			
			Scleral Apertures
			
			 
			
			Structures Transmitted
			
		
		
			
			A.
			
			
			Anterior scleral apertures
			
			
			1.
			
			
			Short and long ciliary arteries
			
		
		
			
			B.
			
			
			Middle scleral apertures
			
			
			2.
			
			
			Central retinal artery and vein
			
		
		
			
			C.
			
			
			Posterior scleral apertures
			
			
			3.
			
			
			Anterior ciliary arteries and veins
			
		
		
			
			D.
			
			
			Lamina cribrosa
			
			
			4.
			
			
			Vortex veins
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2

 

Explanation:

 

  • The anterior scleral apertures transmit the anterior ciliary arteries and veins, while the middle scleral apertures allow passage for the vortex veins.
  • The posterior scleral apertures transmit the short and long ciliary arteries.
  • The Lamina cribrosa is where the central retinal artery and vein enter the sclera.

 

Apertures of the sclera:

Apertures

Location

Structures transmitted

Anterior

3-4 mm posterior to the limbus

Anterior ciliary vessels, nerves, and lymphatics

Middle

4 to 7 mm behind the equator

4 vortex veins (Vena verticose)

Posterior

Around the optic nerve
  • 8 to 20 short ciliary vessels (circle of Zinn) and nerves
  • 2 long posterior ciliary arteries anterior to short ciliary

Lamina cribrosa

Posterior most
  • Optic nerve fibers
  • Central retinal artery and veins.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old patient presents with painless redness of the eye. The ophthalmologist performed a diagnostic test using 2.5% phenylephrine, and no change was noticed. When 10% phenylephrine is used, the following change occurs. What is the most likely diagnosis?


	Before application of 10% phenylephrine:





	After application of 10% phenylephrine:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Episcleritis

 

Explanation:

  • The patient has painless redness of the eye which blanches (as shown in the image) following the application of 10% phenylephrine, suggesting episcleritis.

 

Episcleritis

Definition

Episcleritis refers to inflammation of the loose connective tissue between the sclera and the conjunctiva

Etiology
  • Idiopathic
  • Systemic diseases - gout, rosacea, psoriasis, and connective tissue diseases.
  • Hypersensitivity reaction to endogenous tubercular or streptococcal toxins.
  • Infectious episcleritis - herpes zoster virus, syphilis, Lyme disease, and tuberculosis.

Clinical features
  • Common in young females
  • Acute onset redness
  • Discomfort - gritty/foreign body sensation
  • Mild to no pain
  • Resolves spontaneously
  • Recurrence is common

Clinical types

Simple episcleritis:

  • Sectorial (occasionally diffuse) inflammation of episclera.
  • The engorged episcleral vessels are large and run in a radial direction beneath the conjunctiva

Nodular episcleritis:

  • Pink or purple flat nodule surrounded by injection, usually situated 2-3 mm away from the limbus.
  • The nodule is firm, tender can be moved separately from the sclera and the overlying conjunctiva also moves freely.

Diagnosis

10% Topical phenylephrine blanches overlying conjunctival vessels and inflamed episcleral vessels.

Differential diagnosis
  • Conjunctivitis, which is more superficial; blanching occurs with 2.5% phenylephrine (Option A ruled out)
  • Phlyctenulosis
  • Inflamed pinguecula
  • Scleritis, which is deeper and more painful; does not blanch with 10% phenylephrine (Option B ruled out)

Treatment

  • Topical NSAIDs
  • Topical mild corticosteroid eye drops
  • Topical artificial tears,
  • Cold compresses applied to the closed lids may offer symptomatic relief from ocular discomfort.
  • Systemic NSAIDs

 

Uveitis (Option D) is associated with pain, redness, photophobia, and excess lacrimation, with associated findings in slit lamp examination, which are not seen here.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of episcleritis. After taking a detailed history and performing a thorough systemic examination, which of the following investigations would you consider ordering?

choices.text: Full blood count and rheumatoid factor (RF)
VDRL and X-rays of the chest and sacroiliac joints

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

  • Episcleritis can be associated with systemic conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis (RF), systemic lupus erythematosus (ANA), and other systemic infections or inflammatory diseases that may be assessed with the Mantoux test (Tuberculosis) and VDRL (Syphilis).
  • X-rays of the chest and sacroiliac joints can help rule out conditions like ankylosing spondylitis, which can also present with episcleritis.
  • Therefore, a comprehensive approach including all listed investigations is appropriate.

 

Conditions associated with Episcleritis:

  • Idiopathic: The exact etiology is unknown in many cases.

 

  • Systemic Diseases:
    • Gout
    • Rosacea
    • Psoriasis
    • Connective tissue diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, lupus)
  • Hypersensitivity Reactions:
    • Endogenous tubercular toxins
    • Streptococcal toxins
  • Infectious Episcleritis:
    • Herpes zoster virus
    • Syphilis
    • Lyme disease
    • Tuberculosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a 15-year history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) presents with severe ocular pain, redness, and progressively worsening vision in her left eye for the past 2 weeks. Examination reveals a localized area of scleral thinning with adjacent congestion. There is no posterior involvement on B-scan ultrasound. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Necrotizing scleritis with inflammation

 

Explanation:

 

  • Severe pain, scleral thinning with adjacent congestion are hallmark signs of necrotizing scleritis, the most severe form of RA-associated scleritis.
  • RA leads to immune-mediated vasculitis, causing ischemic necrosis of the sclera.


 

Classification of Scleritis:

 

Anterior Staphyloma (Option A):

  • Anterior staphyloma is a late-stage complication, where uveal tissue bulges through a thinned, scarred sclera.
  • This patient has active inflammation, whereas staphyloma occurs after chronic necrosis and healing.

 

Nodular Scleritis (Option C):

  • Nodular scleritis presents with discrete, firm nodules on the sclera, without necrosis.
  • This patient has scleral thinning and avascular necrosis, which rules out nodular scleritis.

 

Scleromalacia Perforans (Option D):

  • Scleromalacia perforans is a form of necrotizing scleritis WITHOUT inflammation (painless, non-red eye).
  • This patient has severe pain and congestion, so active necrotizing scleritis is the correct choice.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with persistent eye discomfort, redness, and watering. On examination, the left eye is diffusely tender, sclera appears uniformly reddened and swollen without localized thinning areas. There are no systemic signs of vasculitis or autoimmune disease on further investigation. Which type of anterior scleritis is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non-necrotizing anterior diffuse scleritis

 

Explanation:

  • Clinical presentation of persistent eye discomfort, watering, diffuse redness, and tenderness without localized necrosis or thinning is characteristic of non-necrotizing anterior diffuse scleritis.

 

Anterior Scleritis:

  • Most common in elderly female patients ( 40-70 years)
  • Etiology: Associated with connective tissue disease (50% of cases)

 

Clinical classification:

  • Non-necrotizing anterior scleritis
    • Diffuse
    • Nodular
  • Necrotizing anterior scleritis
    • With inflammation
    • Without inflammation

Non-necrotizing anterior scleritis:

  • Pain, redness, watering, discharge, and bluish or brownish discoloration.
  • Nodular: One or more dark red or bluish nodules, which later become purple and semitransparent like porcelain. (Option C ruled out)
  • Diffuse (most common): Diffuse or localized congestion (Option B)

 

Treatment:

  • First-line
    • Topical steroids eye drops
    • Oral NSAIDs
  • Second-line
    • Systemic steroids

Necrotizing anterior scleritis:

  • Necrosis of sclera
  • Severe thinning, and melting in severe cases

 

With inflammation: (Option A ruled out)

  • Severe form of scleritis
  • Red, painful eye, and progressive worsening of symptoms

Without inflammation (Scleromalacia perforans): (Option D ruled out)

Painless scleral thinning

 

Treatment:

  • Topical steroids eye drops
  • High dose of oral steroids
  • Non-responsive cases
  • Immunosuppressive agents
  • Surgical treatment: scleral patch graft in severe cases to preserve the integrity of the globe due to severe thinning and melting.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with severe pain in her right eye, worsened by eye movements, and reduced vision. On examination, proptosis and restricted ocular movements were observed. Ophthalmoscopy shows disc, macular edema, and choroidal folds. Which of the following B-scan ultrasonography findings is most indicative of this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) T sign

 

Explanation:

  • Given the clinical presentation of severe pain in the eye, proptosis, restricted ocular movements, reduced vision, disc, and macular edema, and the potential findings of choroidal folds, the diagnosis most consistent with these symptoms is posterior scleritis.
  • Thickening of the posterior sclera, retrobulbar thickening, and fluid surrounding the optic nerve creates a characteristic “T” sign in B-scan ultrasound.

 

Posterior scleritis:

  • Inflammation with thickening of the posterior sclera

 

Clinical manifestations:

  • Decreased vision, with or without pain
  • Proptosis
  • Restricted ocular movements
  • Posterior vitiates
  • Disc and macular oedema
  • Choroidal folds
  • Choroidal detachment
  • Uveal effusion syndrome
  • Exudative retinal detachment

 

Diagnosis:

  • USG-B scan shows T sign (Pathognomonic finding): (Option A)
    • It represents the fluid accumulation between the optic nerve and the sclera
    • It is the name given to the shape of the scleral thickening: Each arm of the T represents the posterior sclera with the stem as the optic nerve.

 

  • Others-CT, MRI

Treatment:

  • Systemic NSAIDs
  • Systemic steroids
  • Immunosuppressive therapy
  • Biologics: Infliximab and rituximab

 

Moth-Eaten Appearance (Option B): Seen in Retinoblastoma, characterized by intraocular calcifications, typically in children, not adults.

 

Sunray Sign (Option C): Seen in Choroidal Melanoma, due to radial vascularity, but this patient lacks an intraocular mass.

 

Kiss Sign (Option D): Seen in Total Retinal Detachment, where the detached retina folds inward, but this case has no retinal involvement.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a 20-year history of rheumatoid arthritis has a painless, progressively thinning area in the sclera of her left eye. The area appears as shown in the image below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiological mechanism responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Type III hypersensitivity

 

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis in this scenario is scleromalacia perforans.
  • It is usually associated with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis and presents with scleral thinning appearing bluish and without signs of inflammation.
  • The underlying cause of scleral thinning is probably ischemia because of vessel damage (type III hypersensitivity).

 

Scleromalacia Perforans:

  • Most common in elderly females.

Pathophysiology:

  • Associated with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Melting of the sclera is due to obliteration of arterial supply causing ischemia.
  • Vessel damage is mediated by type III hypersensitivity. 

 

Clinical manifestations:

  • Painless scleral thinning
  • Underlying dark uveal tissue is visible
  • Rarely perforation of the globe

Treatment:

  • No specific therapy
  • Protection of the eye from trauma is very crucial
  • Plenty of topical lubrication
  • Oral NSAIDs
  • Oral steroids
  • Immunomodulatory agents
  • Surgery-scleral patch grafting

 

Type II hypersensitivity (Option B): This involves antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction or destruction, which doesn't directly explain the immune complex deposition and vasculitis seen in scleromalacia perforans.

Type IV hypersensitivity (Option C): While cell-mediated immunity is crucial in rheumatoid arthritis, the direct mechanism of vasculitis and subsequent ischemic necrosis in scleromalacia perforans is more specifically linked to immune complex deposition rather than delayed-type hypersensitivity.

Infective etiology (Option D): Scleromalacia perforans is a sterile, autoimmune complication of systemic diseases like rheumatoid arthritis, not caused by a direct bacterial, fungal, or viral infection.

questions.text: Depending on the location of the staphyloma in the eye which among the following options is matched correctly with its cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Equatorial staphyloma - scleritis

 

Explanation:

  • The causes of equatorial staphyloma are scleritis, degenerative myopia, and chronic uncontrolled glaucoma.

 

Staphyloma:

  • It is ectasia of the outer coats of the eye (cornea, sclera, or both) with an incarceration of the uveal tissue.
  • Based on the site affected, staphyloma can be classified as:

 

Types of staphyloma

Causes

Anterior (Option A ruled out)

Pseudocornea

Intercalary (Option B ruled out)

Perforating injuries of the peripheral cornea, marginal corneal ulcer, anterior scleritis, and scleromalacia perforans

Ciliary (Option D ruled out)

Glaucoma, scleritis, and trauma to the ciliary region

Equatorial (approx 14 mm behind the limbus) (Option C)

Scleritis, degenerative myopia, and chronic uncontrolled glaucoma

Posterior

Degenerative high axial myopia

Treatment:

  • Treat underlying condition
  • Local excision and repair with a corneal and scleral patch graft
  • Large staphyloma: Staphylectomy and keratoplasty, or enucleated and replaced with an implant

questions.text: Blue sclera is commonly associated with all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Alkaptonuria

 

Explanation:

  • Yellow-brown or blue-black pigment deposition occurs in different parts of the eye in alkaptonuria.
  • Classic scleral pigment deposits are called “Osler’s sign.

Blue sclera:

Uveal pigment shines through the thin sclera and produces the blue color

 

Causes:

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option A ruled out)
  • Ehlers–Danlos syndrome (Option B ruled out)
  • Marfan syndrome (Option D ruled out)
  • Pseudoxanthoma elasticum
  • Scleromalacia perforans
